content.webTitle: The sandwich degree: how to fill your course with a dream placement

fields.headline: The sandwich degree: how to fill your course with a dream placement
fields.bodyText: When Heidi Hawkins applied for her degree in business management at the University of Huddersfield, the sandwich year was the main appeal. “I was interested in marketing, but didn’t take it as a degree subject. I thought spending a year working in the industry would confirm whether it should be my future career,” she says. “The application procedure was draining. Eventually I secured my placement in communications at an NHS hospital after endless applications and four interviews. But it was worth it, and I now have a full-time job in marketing.” The sandwich degree – which incorporates a year working in industry, rather than a BA in baguette-making – is beloved by students for its employability boost. But, like Hawkins, many find the application process daunting – especially when looking for a role in an area without many formal sandwich placements. Here recruiters, university careers experts and graduates reveal the best way to secure a dream placement. Start early. Most schemes ask for applications in October of the year before your placement. But Anne Patton, placement officer at the University of East Anglia, says: “Some vacancies are advertised during late summer and autumn. And some of the really large organisations open and close their vacancies before students return to university, so it pays to be ready over the summer.” Don’t leave your application to the last minute. “Some employers close their vacancies once they find the right candidates, so apply as soon as you can,” she adds. Look for opportunities everywhere. Start with your university’s online jobs board as well as portals like Ratemyplacement and Milkround, but make sure you track the more general jobs websites, too, as smaller firms may advertise year-long positions there. Careers fairs are a good place to network and grill employers about any opportunities. Network. If you do meet a potential contact, “take their business card and make a note of your conversation with them,” advises Abigail Swain, placement officer at the University of Westminster. “It’s easy to forget what was talked about if you’ve spoken to so many people in the same day. Send them a personalised email, referencing the conversation you had – that’s more likely to get a reply.” Look beyond the major firms. Smaller firms and startups tend to offer interns more things to do. But if you focus on a niche industry, or a firm that doesn’t offer formal schemes, you’ll have to do more groundwork, advises Kate Hastings, placements adviser at Newcastle University careers service. “Speak to your careers service to sound out ideas and have your covering letter checked.” Be personal. Tailor your CV and covering letter for every application. Even though it’s time-consuming, ensuring your application highlights the skills or requirements of a specific company and placement is vital. When you approach a firm about a potential placement try to find a named person, rather than writing to a generic “Sir or Madam”. If the company website doesn’t list an HR contact, a phone call or LinkedIn might help. Don’t give up. “Lots of students feel demoralised if they haven’t been offered a placement by Christmas and stop looking,” says Hastings. “But there are still lots of good opportunities to be found at that stage, potentially with smaller organisations who might be able to offer higher responsibility levels and a unique experience. It’s worth persevering.”
